Expectation1: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation1: A storm advisory for tonight mentions possible delays and the elderly neighbor lives alone on the same floor.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: A patient has just received a difficult diagnosis and is visibly distressed and crying.
Story: The wind rattled the windows as I glanced at my phone—storm advisory, possible delays, and my elderly neighbor, Mrs. Kim, lived alone just down the hall. I remembered her anxious face last week, asking if I could check in if the weather got bad. At the same time, my shift at the care home was ending, but I couldn’t leave yet. Mr. Alvarez, one of my patients, had just received a devastating diagnosis. He was crying, clutching my hand, needing comfort and reassurance. My supervisor expected me to stay with him, to offer the emotional support he desperately needed. But Mrs. Kim would be waiting, maybe scared, maybe needing help if the power went out. I felt torn, my mind racing between the two places I was needed most. The weight of both roles pressed on me—one as a neighbor, the other as a nursing assistant—each demanding my presence, each expecting me to care. I stood in the hallway, heart pounding, caught between the storm outside and the storm of emotions inside.
